                       int resolution)

        Parameters:
        mt - - a MIDITrack which already has notes and events.
        resolution -
        Returns:

      • trackFromMIDITrack

        public static Track trackFromMIDITrack(MIDITrack mt,
                       Sequence sequence)
        trackFromMIDITrack creates a new JavaSound Track that belongs to the supplied Sequence. The MIDITrack is iterated and MidiEvent objects (patch, note on/off, eotrack) are created and placed into the Track. MIDIUtils is used to insert events into the Track. Both the MIDITrack's MIDIEvents and MIDINotes are iterated. Beats are 1 based, but ticks are zero based. This does the conversion. Each MIDINote's bank and program are used. There will be a bank select control message and a program change message if the current values are different from the previous values (i.e. each MIDINote has a bank and program. The first MIDINote will send the change messages. Those messages are sent from succeeding MIDINotes only if the values are different.) Called from the ScoreFactory method scoreToSequence(). The new Track is returned, but it is already part of the Sequence, so that's just for debugging or some other use.
        Parameters:
        sequence - a JavaSound Sequence instance
        Returns:
        a JavaSound Track instance, which is already part of the Sequence
        See Also:
        ScoreFactory.scoreToSequence(Score), MIDIUtils

      • trackToMIDITrack

        public static MIDITrack trackToMIDITrack(Track t,
                         int resolution)
        trackToMIDITrack turns a collection of MidiEvents containing ShortMessages only (e.g. no sysex) into a MIDITrack. The Note Messages are placed in notes as MIDINotes, other messages wrapped and are placed in a separate list - the instance variable events

        You might get the division like this: double div = (double) sequence.getResolution();

        Parameters:
        t - a Track to be converted
        resolution - a int sequence PPQ resolution aka division
        Returns:
        a MIDITrack

      • createFromIntervals

        public static MIDITrack createFromIntervals(int[] intervals,
                            int baseInt,
                            int unit,
                            boolean absolute)
        createFromIntervals generates a MIDITrack from the provided intervals. Only the pitches in the Notes are set.
        Parameters:
        intervals - an int[] containing the intervals.
        baseInt - an int that will be the first Note pitch in the series.
        unit - an int that each interval is multiplied
        absolute - a boolean whether the intervals are in relation to the baseInt
        Returns:
        a MIDITrack

      • getTrackPattern

        public static MIDITrack getTrackPattern(int[] degrees,
                        int[] pattern,
                        int limit,
                        int startingMIDINumber,
                        int nOctaves,
                        double duration,
                        boolean reverse,
                        double restBetweenPatterns,
                        boolean upAndDown)
        Iteratively apply a pattern to an array of scale degrees. Actually any interval pattern; you can use a Chord or a Scale for example. If you want the degrees you can do this: int[] degrees = Interval.intervalsToDegrees(chord.getIntervals(), numOcts); or if it is a scale this scale.getDegrees() The pattern for the first Hanon exercise would be 0 2 3 4 5 4 3 2
        Parameters:
        degrees - the degrees
        pattern - the pattern
        limit - - max index into degrees
        startingMIDINumber - starting MIDI pitch
        nOctaves - number of octaves
        duration - duration
        reverse - should reverse the pattern
        restBetweenPatterns - gap between patterns
        upAndDown - make it go up and down
        Returns:
        a MIDITrack

      • applyPattern

        public static MIDITrack applyPattern(MIDITrack track,
                     Integer[] patternArray,
                     boolean reverse)
        the pattern is a collection of indices into the notelist. no bounds checking Integer[] pattern = new Integer[] 0, 0, 3, 2, 1 ; MIDITrack patterned = MIDITrackFactory .applyPattern( notelist, pattern); } A cleaner replacement for getNoteListPattern(blah blah) but doesn't do the hanon like sequencing - which you can do externally
        Parameters:
        track - a track
        patternArray - a pattern array
        reverse - reverse the pattern
        Returns:
        a MIDITrack

      • embellish

        public static MIDITrack embellish(MIDITrack original,
                  int[] intervalPattern)
        Every note in the original is followed by new notes based on the intervals. Start beats are not calculated. Do something else for those. 
         Scale major = ScaleFactory.createFromName("Major");
 major.setOctave(5);
 int[] intervalPattern = { 0, 2, 0, -1 };
 MIDITrack scale = ScaleFactory.createMIDITrack(major);
 MIDITrack embellished = embellish(scale, intervalPattern);
 Staffer.showTrebleStaff(embellished, "Major scale embellished");
        Parameters:
        original -
        intervalPattern -
        Returns:

      • modifyPitchIntervals

        public static MIDITrack modifyPitchIntervals(MIDITrack track,
                             CircularList<Integer> values,
                             boolean absolute)
        Track ints = MIDITrackFactory.createFromIntervals(1, 2, 3, 4, 5); CircularList<Integer> values = new CircularArrayList<Integer>(); values.add(1); MIDITrack modints = MIDITrackFactory.modifyPitchIntervals(ints, values, true); // so intervals 1 2 3 4 5 become 2 3 4 5 6
        Parameters:
        track - the track
        values - the values added to the intervals
        absolute - is absolute
        Returns:
        a MIDITrack created from the intervals
